stem: The patient's recent ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. This finding is MOST consistent with an acute [BLANK] myocardial infarction.

mnemonic.title: ECG Lead Locations
mnemonic.description: Remember ECG lead locations for different MI types: 'ALLS' - Anterior, Lateral, Lateral, Septal. Inferior (II, III, aVF) is often paired with Right Ventricular (RV) MI.

rationale.incorrect: The ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is indicative of an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which is typically caused by occlusion of the right coronary artery or the left circumflex artery. This area of the heart is supplied by these arteries, and blockage leads to ischemia and infarction.

questionTrap.rationale1: An anterior wall MI typically presents with ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V4. These leads correspond to the anterior surface of the left ventricle.
questionTrap.rationale2: A lateral wall MI typically presents with ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. These leads reflect the lateral aspect of the left ventricle.
questionTrap.rationale3: A septal wall MI typically presents with ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2. These leads view the interventricular septum.

clinicalPearls: ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF strongly suggests an inferior wall MI. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to minimize myocardial damage.
Reciprocal ST-segment depression in lateral leads (I, aVL) can further support the diagnosis of inferior MI. Look for these changes to confirm your suspicion.
Right ventricular involvement should be considered in inferior MIs, especially with hypotension. Assess for RV infarction signs and symptoms.

itemContext.sbar:
S: The patient is a 68-year-old male presenting to the ED at 14:30, reporting severe chest pain that began approximately 2 hours prior. He describes the pain as a crushing pressure in the center of his chest, radiating to his left arm. 
B: The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. His current medications include lisinopril 20mg daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily. No known allergies. 
A: The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Initial ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels have been drawn and are pending. Blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 24 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.
R: I recommend immediate cardiology consultation, initiation of MONA protocol (morphine, oxygen, nitroglycerin, aspirin), and continuous ECG monitoring. Prepare for potential percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
